Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The effects of nectar robbery on territorial pollinators and plant reproduction
Award.AbstractNarration:
Pollination is a critical process for plant reproduction that sustains ecosystems and bolsters global biodiversity. Of all known factors that may impact pollination, nectar robbery is one of the least understood. Nectar robbery refers to when an animal extracts nectar from a flower without providing the reciprocal service of pollen delivery or pollen receipt, and is usually done by creating a small hole in the base of the flower. This research is expected to improve our understanding of how nectar robbery impacts the delicate balance between plants and pollinators. This knowledge will help us to better understand the evolution of nectar robbery and its potential role in the conservation of pollination networks. Undergraduates in the US and Peru will gain experience by participation in the research, and STEM excitement communicated through the Tulane University Girls in Science and Technology program. The research itself promotes the progress of science through improved understanding of the dimensions of pollination, which has implications for national welfare; the project also supports education and diversity in a project with K-12 students.

This research will investigate the effects of nectar robbery by Diglossa flowerpiercers (Family: Thraupidae) on the foraging ecology of hummingbird pollinators will be investigated, and the consequences for pollen flow and reproduction of the Andean plant Oreocallis grandiflora (Family: Proteaceae) assessed. The response of territorial hummingbird pollinators to nectar robbery in terms of spatial behavior and foraging ecology will be quantified using radio telemetry tracking. The hypothesis that nectar robbery may have a positive effect on plant reproduction via improved outcrossing rates caused by an increase in visitation by non-resident pollinators in the absence of resident territorial pollinators will be tested. Research experience will be provided to undergraduates in the US and Peru, and the research process will be communicated to K-12 students in the Tulane University Girls in Science and Technology program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The study of plant-animal mutualistic relationships, especially in terms of plants and their pollinators, is a critical area of research. Pollination processes are essential for the reproduction of many plant species and sustain biodiversity on a global scale. Nectar robbing is a widespread natural phenomenon that impacts plant-pollinator mutualisms on a global scale, and refers to whenever an animal removes nectar from a flower without providing any reciprocal pollination service. Nectar robbing is generally accomplished by creating an incision in the side of the flower through which nectar is removed, and which bypasses any contact with the pollen or ovaries of the flower. The study of nectar robbing, and how plants and pollinators respond to it, can further our understanding of ecological cause-and-effect, the evolution and maintenance of pollination mutualisms, and even how pollination mutualisms might respond to human-induced changes to plants, pollinators, and the environment. This study was one of the first to research how nectar robbing impacts the plant-pollinator mutualism from the perspective of the pollinator.

Previous research has focused primarily on its effects on the reproduction of plants. In this DDIG-funded study, we conducted nectar robbing experiments on the territories of hummingbirds in the Andes of Peru and Ecuador. We actually physically tracked the responses of hummingbirds by attaching small radio-telemetry tags to them, which allowed us to measure how they changed their movement patterns, diet, and activity budgets during the day in response to widespread nectar robbing on their territories. We found a significant shift in the movement patterns and diet of the hummingbirds, but no change in their activity budgets, in response to nectar robbing. This suggests that nectar robbing may have long-term impacts on pollinator survival and reproduction, but also that pollinators have a range of behavioral strategies available to them in the case of alterations made to their nectar supply.

As a result of DDIG funding, a doctoral student (Jenny Hazlehurst) was able to complete this study and incorporate it into her doctoral dissertation, which was completed in April 2016, helping to improve the representation of women in Academia. Funding also streamlined the publication of one paper in a peer-reviewed journal by the doctoral student, as well as submission of two additional manuscripts to peer-reviewed journals. Several public talks were given both at field sites in Peru and Ecuador in Spanish as well as in the U.S. at Tulane University to disseminate the findings of the research. Additionally, during fieldwork 11 field assistants from the U.S., Peru, Canada, and Colombia, some of whom were undergraduate students, received training from the doctoral student and also engaged in valuable teamwork together, encouraging international cooperation and the exchange of culture and ideas. Field assistants also aided in producing laminated bilingual English-Spanish bird guides for field sites in Ecuador and Peru, improving resources for local eco-tourism and environmental education in important hotspots of biodiversity.
